questions.text: At what BMI value is considered 'fatal' for men? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) <13 

 

  • A body mass index (BMI) of less than 13 in men is considered critically low and potentially fatal. 
  • This threshold indicates extreme undernutrition and can lead to severe health complications, potentially resulting in life-threatening conditions due to vital organ function impairment and failure. 
  • BMI is a measure of body fat based on height and weight that applies to adult men and women, and values significantly below normal can indicate serious health risks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An individual with a body mass index (BMI) of 13 or lower is deemed fatal for males. Nonetheless, females can endure with a BMI as low as 11 or even lower.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with a complaint of acute-onset severe abdominal pain. The patient is conscious, alert, and hemodynamically stable. Upon examination, the patient reports that the pain began suddenly. A chest X-ray is performed, which reveals some abnormal findings. Identify the condition shown below and its management?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emergency laparotomy

 

  • Given the clinical picture of acute-onset severe abdominal pain and a chest X-ray showing free air under the diaphragm, the diagnosis of hollow viscus perforation is suspected, and the appropriate management is an emergency laparotomy.
  • A hollow viscus perforation leads to the spillage of enteric contents into the abdominal cavity. This can cause acute peritonitis, a life-threatening inflammation of the peritoneal cavity.
  • Emergency laparotomy is the surgical opening of the abdomen to investigate and treat the cause of the acute abdominal pain. It can confirm the diagnosis, identify the source of the perforation, and treat it, often by repairing or resecting the affected section of the bowel.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastric lavage:

 

  • Gastric lavage, often referred to as "stomach pumping," is a procedure that involves the insertion of a tube into the stomach to remove its contents. It's often used in cases of drug overdose or ingestion of toxic substances.
  • In the context of sudden abdominal pain and air under the diaphragm on an X-ray, this option is not appropriate since the problem is not related to the contents of the stomach but rather a perforation.

 

Option C. Ultrasound:

 

  • While it can be used in the evaluation of various abdominal conditions, in the context of acute severe pain and a suggestive chest X-ray, ultrasound wouldn't be the primary diagnostic modality.
  • Air (as from a perforated viscus) is a poor conductor of ultrasound waves, which makes ultrasound less reliable in this setting compared to other imaging modalities.

 

Option D. Chest tube insertion:

 

  • A chest tube is inserted between the ribs to drain air, blood, or fluid from the pleural space. This is usually done in conditions like pneumothorax, hemothorax, or pleural effusion.
  • While the X-ray may show air under the diaphragm, this air is in the abdomen and not in the pleural space of the chest.
  • Given the acute presentation and the imaging findings, the correct management is emergency laparotomy to address the underlying perforation and prevent further complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hollow viscus perforation is a surgical emergency that presents with acute abdominal pain and may be confirmed by the presence of free air under the diaphragm on a chest X-ray.
  • Immediate surgical intervention, typically via emergency laparotomy, is required to address the perforation and prevent peritonitis.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the following MRI scan:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cerebellum

 

Explanation:

 

The given image shows an MRI of the sagittal section of the brain, where the red arrow points to the Cerebellum. This part of the brain is known for its role in motor control, and it can also be involved in some cognitive functions like attention and language.

 

Key features visible in the MRI that help identify the Cerebellum include its characteristic lobulated structure located at the posterior base of the brain, just below the cerebrum and behind the brainstem and fourth ventricle.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midbrain: Part of the brainstem, located higher and anteriorly relative to the cerebellum on sagittal images.

 

Option C. Brainstem: The brainstem, which includes the midbrain, pons, and medulla, is located anteriorly to the cerebellum in the image.

 

Option D. Cerebrum: The largest part of the brain, covering most of the upper sections of the image, involved in various higher-order functions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Cerebellum, distinct in its appearance and location in the posterior aspect of the brain, plays crucial roles in the coordination of voluntary movements and motor functions, which can be clearly seen on sagittal MRI scans.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with a white pupillary reflex for which enucleation was done. The histopathological examination of the specimen showed Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Retinoblastoma

 

The most likely diagnosis with a histopathological finding of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes in a 7-year-old child with a whitish pupillary reflex is retinoblastoma. Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes refer to an arrangement of columnar cells around a central lumen, which is highly characteristic of retinoblastoma.

 

 

 

  • Retinoblastoma is a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells and is the most common intraocular malignancy in children.
  • It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene at chromosome 13q14.
  • It is a tumour of a group called small round blue cell tumours because the immature retinal neural cells are seen as small round cells with large nuclei.
  • Most common presentation is leukocoria.
  • 2nd most common symptom is squint.
  • Clinical Features:

 

i). Quiescent stage:

  • Characterized by Leukocoria which is also known as Amaurotic cat’s eye appearance, convergent squint, defective vision and nystagmus (seen in bilateral cases).
  • Ophthalmoscopically, endophytic retinoblastoma gives “cottage cheese appearance” whereas exophytic tumor present as exudative retinal detachment.

 

ii). Glaucomatous stage:

  • Presents as severe pain, redness and watering. It may also result in hyphemia or pseudo hypopyon (contains tumor cells).

 

iii). Extraocular extension:

  • Globe burst through sclera near limbus and presents as marked proptosis.

 

iv). Distant metastasis:

  • Metastasis of retinoblastoma spread to
  • Optic nerve via direct extension
  • Pre-auricular lymph nodes via lymphatics
  • Cranial bones via blood
  • Microscopy – Flexner-Winter Steiner rosettes.
  • Treatment:
  • Enucleation
  • Chemotherapy→ intra-arterial chemo – melphalan in ophthalmic artery is very successful.
  • VEC is very successful:
  • V – Vincristine
  • E – Etoposide
  • C – Carboplatin

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medulloblastoma: A malignant brain tumor located in the posterior fossa, not associated with intraocular findings or leukocoria.

 

Option C. Rhabdomyosarcoma: A soft tissue sarcoma affecting muscles, often presenting as a mass in the orbit but not causing leukocoria or associated with Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.

 

Option D. Astrocytoma: A tumor of the central nervous system (glial origin), which does not occur intraocularly and is not linked with Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes are a hallmark of retinoblastoma, indicating a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells. This specific histopathological finding is crucial for diagnosing retinoblastoma, especially in children presenting with leukocoria.

 

Different rosettes seen in retinoblastoma:
 

1. True rosette -FLEXNER-WINTERSTEINER ROSETTE

  • This is specific for RB - hallmark of RB
  • It consists of tumor cells surrounding a central lumen that contains cytoplasmic extensions from the tumor cells, which have well-differentiated features suggestive of primitive photoreceptor cells.

 

2. HOMER-WRIGHT ROSETTE is a non-specific rosette seen in any of the primitive neuroectodermal tumors. Tumor cells surround a central region containing neutrophil.

 

3. FLUERETTE is pseudo rosette because the central structure is not a part of the tumor and it consists of tumor cells around a blood vessel.

questions.text: The time gap between entry of organism in human body and its maximal infectivity is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Generation time

 

Generation time is defined as the time interval between the entry of an infectious organism into the human body and the period when the individual reaches maximal infectivity. This concept is crucial in understanding the spread of infectious diseases, as it indicates when an infected person is most likely to transmit the infection to others.

 

Generation time helps public health professionals predict the spread of disease and is essential in planning control measures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incubation period: This option is incorrect. The incubation period is the time from exposure to the onset of first sign/symptom, not specifically related to the peak of infectivity.

 

Option B. Median IP: This option is incorrect. Median incubation period refers to the time by which 50% of cases exhibit symptoms, unrelated to infectivity.

 

Option C.  Serial IP (Serial Interval Period): This option is incorrect. The serial interval measures the gap between symptom onset in a primary case and a secondary case, not between entry of the organism and peak infectivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Generation time is the interval between the entry of an organism into the body and the point of maximal infectivity.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby is brought to OPD with jaundice and clay-colored stools. Lab work up reveals that the baby has conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. A liver biopsy was done and shows periductal proliferation. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Biliary atresia

 

An infant with jaundice, clay-coloured stools, and periductal proliferation on liver biopsy is highly suggestive of biliary atresia.

 

An infant with Biliary atresia presents with progressive jaundice, persistent yellow stools, and palpable liver with abnormal consistency.

 

Laboratory investigations show conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Ultrasonography reveals a triangular-cord sign (cone-shaped fibrotic mass cranial to the bifurcation of the portal vein).

 

HIDA test is more relevant for its negative predictive value (100%). Liver biopsy is diagnostic for biliary atresia. In biliary atresia, portal tract expansion, ductular proliferation and fibrosis is seen.

 

Laparotomy and perioperative cholangiography may be required in an infant with equivocal biopsy, findings and no excretion on HIDA scan, to evaluate for biliary atresia.

 

Biliary atresia is managed by Kasai procedure (hepato-portoenterostomy).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crigler-Najjar syndrome: This is characterized by absent or deficient UGT enzyme leading to increased unconjugated bilirubin. It does not present with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia or clay-colored stools.

 

Option B. Rotor syndrome: A mild form of Dubin-Johnson syndrome that causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, but without the dark liver appearance seen in Dubin-Johnson syndrome. It does not present with periductal proliferation on liver biopsy.

 

Option C. Dubin-Johnson syndrome: Characterized by increased conjugated bilirubin and a dark liver appearance. It is an autosomal recessive disorder but does not present with the same liver biopsy findings as biliary atresia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An infant presenting with jaundice, clay-colored stools, and periductal proliferation on liver biopsy is highly suggestive of biliary atresia.

questions.text: A patient undergoing surgery is maintained on anesthesia with halothane. During the procedure, the patient suddenly developed hyperthermia and muscle rigidity. Which of the following drugs is most likely implicated in this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Suxamethonium

 

The scenario described involves a patient undergoing surgery who suddenly develops hyperthermia and muscle rigidity. This is indicative of a condition called Malignant Hyperthermia (MH), which is a rare but potentially life-threatening reaction to certain medications used during anesthesia.

 

In this case, the most likely drug implicated in causing MH is:

 

Suxamethonium (also known as succinylcholine)

 

  • Suxamethonium is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent commonly used for muscle relaxation during surgery.
  • However, it is known to be associated with triggering malignant hyperthermia in susceptible individuals.
  • MH is a severe reaction that can cause a rapid increase in body temperature, muscle rigidity, and other complications.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Doxacurium: Doxacurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent used to induce muscle relaxation during surgery. It is not typically associated with causing malignant hyperthermia.

 

Option C. Atracurium: Atracurium is another non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent used in anesthesia. It is not typically associated with causing malignant hyperthermia.

 

Option D. Rocuronium: Rocuronium is also a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent. Like atracurium and doxacurium, it is not typically associated with causing malignant hyperthermia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The drug most likely implicated in causing malignant hyperthermia in the given scenario is suxamethonium (succinylcholine) because it is known to trigger this condition in susceptible individuals.

 

Treatment - Dantrolene sodium and supportive management

choices.text: One basic health worker per 10,000 population
Responsibility of PHCs in malaria eradication

questions.text: The Chadah committee suggested all of the following options except: [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) One PHC for 50,000 population 

 

  • The correct answer, "B. One PHC for 50,000 populations," refers to a recommendation actually made by the Kartar Singh Committee, not the Chadah Committee. 
  • The Chadah Committee was established to assess the necessary arrangements for the Maintenance Phase of the National Malaria Eradication Program (NMEP). 
  • It emphasized integrating vigilance operations of the NMEP within general health services, specifically through PHCs at the block level, and allocating health workers specifically for malaria vigilance, among other public health tasks.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A female patient presented with symptomatic urinary symptoms. On laboratory examination, growth of coagulase negative novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus with >10⁴ colony growth is seen. What is the true statement regarding this? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Consider it as a UTI


The patient has symptomatic urinary symptoms, and the laboratory findings indicate the presence of coagulase-negative, novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus with a colony count greater than 10⁴. These characteristics point towards a urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by Staphylococcus saprophyticus, which is known to be novobiocin-resistant and commonly implicated in UTIs, particularly in females. Since the patient is symptomatic, it is important to treat this condition as a UTI rather than dismissing or labeling it as contamination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Take 3 consecutive urine samples: This option is incorrect because taking 3 consecutive urine samples is usually required for parasitic infections, where organisms are intermittently shed in the urine. For bacterial infections like this one, particularly with a significant growth of a specific organism, this is unnecessary.

 

Option B. No treatment required: This is incorrect as the patient is symptomatic. In symptomatic UTIs, especially with a significant colony count of a known pathogenic organism, treatment is essential. Leaving a symptomatic patient without treatment could lead to worsening of symptoms and complications.

 

Option C. It is a contaminated sample: This is incorrect because contamination is typically suggested when there are multiple types of organisms present or a mix of non-pathogenic flora. In this case, the growth of coagulase-negative, novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus is specific and significant, aligning with clinical symptoms, ruling out contamination.

 

Educational Objective:


When a female patient presents with symptomatic urinary symptoms and lab findings show coagulase-negative, novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus with significant colony growth, it should be considered as a UTI and treated accordingly.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presented with claudication in the forearm, transient loss of vision, and abdominal pain. Femoral pulses were weak. Fundus examination revealed retinal hemorrhages. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Takayasu arteritis

 

Takayasu arteritis, also known as "pulseless disease," is a large vessel vasculitis that primarily affects the aorta and its major branches. It is more common in young Asian females under 40 years old. The clinical presentation includes claudication (typically in the upper limbs due to subclavian artery involvement), weak pulses (particularly in the extremities), and symptoms resulting from ischemia in various organs (e.g., transient loss of vision due to carotid or vertebral artery involvement, abdominal pain due to mesenteric artery involvement).

 

The combination of weak femoral pulses, claudication in the forearm, and retinal hemorrhages is characteristic of Takayasu arteritis. This condition can lead to narrowing or occlusion of major arteries, causing diminished blood flow to the affected regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyarteritis nodosa: Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a medium vessel vasculitis that can cause abdominal pain, claudication, and other systemic symptoms, but it does not typically affect the large vessels and therefore would not explain the weak femoral pulses. PAN is often associated with hepatitis B infection.

 

Option B. Thromboangiitis obliterans: Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger's disease) typically affects young male smokers and primarily involves the small and medium arteries of the extremities. It can cause claudication and ischemic symptoms in the limbs but does not typically cause weak femoral pulses or retinal hemorrhages.

 

Option D. Microscopic polyangiitis: Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) is a small vessel vasculitis that often presents with symptoms related to kidney and lung involvement (e.g., rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage). It does not typically present with claudication or weak pulses in the large vessels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Takayasu arteritis should be considered in young women presenting with symptoms of large vessel occlusion, such as claudication, weak pulses, and ischemic symptoms in various organs. It is characterized by the involvement of the aorta and its major branches, and the diagnosis can be confirmed with imaging studies like CT angiogram or conventional angiography.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male pt presented to your clinic with persistent non-pitting edema in their lower extremities as shown below. What could be the most likely reason for this symptom? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymphedema

 

  • Lymphedema is the likeliest cause.
  • It involves the build-up of protein-rich fluid in tissue interstitial spaces.
  • It shows typical “non-pitting” edema in the second stage of lymphedema.
  • Filariasis is the most common etiology.
  • In severe and long standing cases, skin changes are seen giving the limb an appearance of “Elephantiasis”.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arterial Disorders: Arterial disorders may lead to symptoms such as leg pain, intermittent claudication, and tissue damage due to reduced blood supply. Edema is uncommon.

 

Option C. Venous Disorders: These disorders can encompass conditions like deep vein thrombosis (DVT), varicose veins, chronic venous insufficiency (CVI), and venous ulcers. Venous disorders may result in symptoms like leg swelling, pain, and skin changes, and they can vary in severity. No evidence of skin changes associated with varicose veins are seen.

 

Option D. Coronary Heart Disease: Coronary heart disease (CHD), also known as coronary artery disease (CAD), is a common heart condition where the coronary arteries that supply blood to the heart muscle become narrowed or blocked due to the buildup of fatty deposits (atherosclerosis). CAD may lead to heart failure leading to bilateral lower limb pitting edema, which is not seen in the case above.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lymphedema is characterized by non-pitting edema due to the accumulation of protein-rich fluid in the tissue interstitial spaces. It can lead to significant swelling and skin changes, particularly in the lower extremities, distinguishing it from other causes of edema.

choices.text: FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 < 30%
FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <70%
FEV1/FVC<0.7 and FEV1< 50%
Both A and C

questions.text: The Gold's criteria for very severe COPD is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 < 30%

 

Option A:

 

According to the GOLD (Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease) criteria for staging chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), very severe COPD is classified as Stage IV. This stage is defined by a FEV1/FVC ratio (forced expiratory volume in one second/forced vital capacity) less than 0.7, which indicates the presence of airflow limitation, and a FEV1 less than 30% of the predicted value. This level of FEV1 signifies a very severe reduction in lung function and typically corresponds with significant symptoms and health status impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Note:

 

  • Currently Class C+D have been combined and called Class E
  • Classification of types have been updated.

 

Reference: GOLD 2023 guidelines

questions.text: You discover that there is evidence of cardiac malformation in a fetus during a routine US scan at 16 weeks. What is the minimum level of fasting blood sugar at which you can suspect overt diabetes? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 126 mg/dL

 

Overt diabetes in a patient is diagnosed based on specific blood glucose levels. The criteria for diagnosing overt diabetes are:

 

  • Fasting blood sugar: ≥ 126 mg/dL
  • Random blood sugar: ≥ 200 mg/dL
  • HbA1c: ≥ 6.5%

 

During pregnancy, maternal hyperglycemia, especially during the first trimester when organogenesis occurs, increases the risk of fetal congenital malformations, including cardiac malformations. This is particularly true for women with pre-gestational diabetes, not gestational diabetes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 106 mg/dL: This is incorrect. A fasting blood sugar level of 106 mg/dL does not meet the threshold for diagnosing overt diabetes.

 

Option C. 116 mg/dL: This is incorrect. A fasting blood sugar level of 116 mg/dL is higher than normal but still below the threshold for diagnosing overt diabetes.

 

Option D. 130 mg/dL: This is incorrect. Although higher than the threshold, the minimum level to suspect overt diabetes is 126 mg/dL, not 130 mg/dL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Overt diabetes in pregnancy is diagnosed with a fasting blood sugar level of ≥ 126 mg/dL, and maternal hyperglycemia.

questions.text: Longitudinal growth of a long bone is most likely affected by a fracture involving which of the following regions? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Epiphyseal plate


The epiphyseal plate, also known as the growth plate, is a layer of hyaline cartilage located between the epiphysis (end) and the metaphysis of a long bone. This plate is crucial for the longitudinal growth of bones during childhood and adolescence. Active cell division occurs here, which contributes to the lengthening of the bone. Any damage or fracture at the epiphyseal plate can disrupt this growth process, leading to potential growth abnormalities.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epiphysis: The epiphysis is the rounded end of the long bone but is not directly responsible for bone growth. Fractures here do not significantly impact the longitudinal growth of the bone.

 

Option B. Metaphysis: The metaphysis is the flared part of the bone between the diaphysis and the epiphyseal plate. Although it plays a role in supporting growth, fractures here do not directly disrupt the longitudinal growth as much as a fracture at the epiphyseal plate would.

 

Option C. Diaphysis: The diaphysis is the shaft or central part of the long bone. Fractures in the diaphysis typically affect the strength and integrity of the bone but do not interfere with growth lengthwise.

 

Educational Objective:


The epiphyseal plate is crucial for the longitudinal growth of bones, and fractures here can significantly impact this process.

questions.text: Identify the condition for which Dohlman’s procedure is used: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Zenker's diverticulum

 

Dohlman's procedure is a surgical technique primarily used to treat Zenker's diverticulum. Zenker's diverticulum is a pouch that forms at the junction of the esophagus and pharynx, causing swallowing difficulties, regurgitation, and aspiration. Dohlman's procedure involves endoscopic division of the cricopharyngeal muscle to alleviate the obstruction and diverticulum formation. This method is favored for its minimal invasiveness and effectiveness in managing the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meckel's diverticulum: Meckel's diverticulum is treated with a diverticulectomy, which involves the surgical removal of the diverticulum. This congenital anomaly of the small intestine often presents with bleeding, inflammation, or obstruction.

 

Option C. Bochdalek hernia: Bochdalek hernia, a congenital diaphragmatic hernia, is typically treated with laparotomy or laparoscopic surgery and subsequent hernia repair. This condition involves abdominal organs herniating into the thoracic cavity through a defect in the diaphragm.

 

Option D. Menetrier's disease: Menetrier's disease, a rare disorder characterized by hypertrophic gastric folds and protein-losing gastropathy, does not have a specific surgical procedure for treatment. Management often includes supportive care, protein supplements, and medications such as proton pump inhibitors or cetuximab.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dohlman's procedure is specifically used to treat Zenker's diverticulum by endoscopic division of the cricopharyngeal muscle to relieve symptoms caused by the diverticulum.

choices.text: Development of cardiac failure within 5 months of delivery

questions.text: All are true regarding peripartum cardiomyopathy except? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Left ventricular diastolic dysfunction

 

Explanation:

 

Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM) is a form of heart failure that occurs during the last month of pregnancy or within five months postpartum. It is characterized by left ventricular systolic dysfunction, rather than diastolic dysfunction. The diagnostic criteria for PPCM include:

 

  • Cardiac failure developing in the last month of pregnancy or within five months after delivery.
  • Absence of an identifiable cause for the cardiac failure.
  • Absence of recognizable heart disease prior to the last month of pregnancy.
  • Echocardiographic evidence of left ventricular systolic dysfunction (ejection fraction <45% or fractional shortening <30%) along with a dilated left ventricle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Development of cardiac failure within 5 months of delivery: Correct. PPCM develops within five months of delivery.

 

Option C. Absence of identifiable cause: Correct. PPCM is diagnosed in the absence of an identifiable cause for cardiac failure.

 

Option D. Dilated left ventricle: Correct. PPCM is associated with a dilated left ventricle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peripartum cardiomyopathy is characterized by left ventricular systolic dysfunction and occurs within the last month of pregnancy or up to five months postpartum, in the absence of an identifiable cause for cardiac failure.

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482185/

questions.text: A woman with a history of infertility is on treatment with human gonadotropin. She presented with the following finding in the USG. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome

 

  • The image is a transvaginal ultrasound showing the ovaries which appear significantly enlarged with fluid in the pelvic cavity (the black spaces seen in between the ovaries)
  • In view of her history of controlled ovarian hyperstimulation in IVF, the answer is OHSS
    • Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is characterized by multiple ovarian follicular cysts accompanied by increased capillary permeability and leakage of intravascular fluid to the third space.
    • It is commonly seen after exogenous administration of FSH, LH or HCG injections.
    • Multiple enlarged follicles are arranged in a necklace pattern in bilateral ovaries.
    • The mainstay of management is conservative. The ongoing stimulation cycle is suspended, and further administration of exogenous gonadotropins are stopped in that cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Theca lutein cysts: Enlarged cysts seen in molar pregnancy, not related to the provided scenario or ultrasound findings.

 

Option C. Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS): PCOS is a risk factor for OHSS, but given the history and the ultrasound image, OHSS is the more appropriate answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

OHSS is characterized by multiple enlarged ovarian follicles and fluid accumulation in the pelvic cavity, often occurring after exogenous gonadotropin administration in infertility treatments.

 

Ref: Page no 456, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: A post-COVID patient, who is a known diabetic, develops unilateral facial pain and loosening of teeth. Which investigation would you do to confirm the diagnosis on this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biopsy with histopathologic examination

 

The given scenario of a post-COVID diabetic patient with facial pain and loosening of teeth is suggestive of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis. Among the given options, Biopsy with histopathologic examination would be the investigation for definitive diagnosis on this patient.

 

The primary reason that appears to be facilitating Mucorales spores to germinate in people with COVID-19 is

 

  1.  An ideal environment of low oxygen (hypoxia)
  2. high glucose (diabetes, new-onset hyperglycemia, steroid-induced hyperglycemia)
  3. Acidic medium (metabolic acidosis, diabetic ketoacidosis [DKA])
  4. High iron levels (increased ferritins)
  5. Decreased phagocytic activity of white blood cells (WBC) due to immunosuppression (SARS-CoV-2 mediated, steroid-mediated or background comorbidities) coupled with several other shared risk factors including prolonged hospitalization with or without mechanical ventilators

 

Rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis is the most common form of mucormycosis. It commonly occurs in patients with diabetes mellitus.

 

The presenting features are facial pain, numbness, loosening of teeth, conjunctival swelling, congestion, and blurry vision. When the disease spreads to the orbit, proptosis can be present. Due to invasion of the blood vessels, mucor fungus causes ischemic necrosis presenting as a black eschar, involving inferior turbinate, palate or the sinus. It can later spread to the frontal lobe of the brain and cavernous sinus.

 

 

 

Confirmation of diagnosis is by biopsy and histopathologic examination which shows aseptate fungi with thick-walled, ribbon-like, hyphae branching at right angles.

 

 

MRI is more sensitive to detecting orbital and nervous involvement than CT.

 

Contrast-enhanced MRI is the imaging technique of choice – black turbinate sign is seen

 

 

Post-contrast T1-weighted coronal MR image shows non enhancing soft tissue, “black turbinate sign,” within the left maxillary sinus (asterisk). The mucosa of the inferior turbinate and a portion of the left middle turbinate demonstrate focal lack of the enhancement (arrowheads).

 

Management

 

  • Antifungal therapy with Amphotericin B
  •  Surgical debridement of the affected tissues.
  •  Treatment of underlying cause
  • Control of blood sugars in diabetic patients

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): Useful for assessing the extent of disease, especially in identifying orbital and central nervous system involvement. It provides detailed images that help in planning the extent of surgical debridement.

 

Option C. Serum Ferritin: Elevated ferritin levels are commonly seen in mucormycosis due to the fungus’s use of iron from the host, which aids its growth. While not diagnostic, high ferritin levels can support the suspicion of mucormycosis in the right clinical context.

 

Option D. HbA1c (Glycated Hemoglobin): This test reflects long-term glucose control and is crucial in managing diabetic patients. Although it does not diagnose mucormycosis, poor glycemic control indicated by a high HbA1c value is a risk factor for the development of fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early diagnosis and aggressive treatment are critical for patients suspected of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis, especially in those with risk factors like diabetes and a recent COVID-19 infection. A biopsy with histopathologic examination is essential for confirming the diagnosis. This condition requires a multidisciplinary approach involving antifungal therapy, surgical debridement, and meticulous management of underlying conditions like diabetes to prevent serious complications and improve outcomes.

choices.text: Rupture of valve
Calcification and fibrosis
Hypertrophy of ventricular wall
Hypertrophy of the atrial wall

questions.text: A 47-year-old female patient with a long-standing history of rheumatic heart disease was admitted to hospital due to severe breathlessness. She died on the 3rd day following admission. The mitral valve shows the following findings on autopsy. What is the cause of these findings? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calcification and Fibrosis

 

The illustration depicts rheumatic heart disease and mitral stenosis with a fish mouth or buttonhole appearance. Calcification and fibrosis are the causes.

 

RHD is primarily identified by mitral stenosis, for which it is essentially the primary cause, and deforming fibrotic valvular disease.

 

The leaflet thickening, commissural fusion and shortening, and thickening and fusing of the tendinous cords are the three primary anatomic alterations of the mitral valve in chronic RHD.

 

"Fish mouth" or "buttonhole" stenosis are caused by calcification and fibrous bridging over the valvular commissures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rupture of valve: Not indicated in the image or history provided.

 

Option C. Hypertrophy of ventricular wall: While ventricular wall hypertrophy may occur due to increased workload from valvular heart disease, it is not visible on this image of the valve.

 

Option D. Hypertrophy of the atrial wall: Similar to ventricular hypertrophy, atrial wall hypertrophy may occur in response to increased pressure from stenosed valves but is not the direct cause visible in the valve image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with a history of rheumatic heart disease, the mitral valve often undergoes significant morphological changes due to fibrosis and calcification, leading to stenosis with a characteristic "fish mouth" appearance. Understanding these changes is crucial for diagnosing and managing the progression of the disease.

choices.text: Discontinue the packet and start an alternate method of contraception
Take 4 tablets the next day, continue the remaining packet, use additional contraception (condom) and give Emergency Pill if h/o intercourse in the last 72 h
Take the next pill as soon as possible, continue the remaining packet, use additional contraception (condom) and give Emergency Pill if h/o intercourse in the last 72 h
Take the next pill as soon as possible and continue the remaining tablets

questions.text: Reema Devi, A 28y newly married woman presents to your sub center for contraceptive advice. She is started on Oral Contraceptive Pills. She presents after 2 weeks with a history of missing 4 tablets on different days in the first 2 weeks of the cycle. What will you advise her? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Take the next pill as soon as possible, continue the remaining packet, use additional contraception (condom) and give Emergency Pill if h/o intercourse in the last 72 h

 

 

Missing a pill increases the risk of pregnancy.

 

Management of Missed Pill

 

 

** In this question, she has missed 4 pills in the 1st 2 weeks Hence, she should take the last missed pill, use additional contraception, use emergency contraception, and continue the remaining pack

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Discontinue the packet and start an alternate method of contraception: Discontinuing the packet is not advised as it can lead to hormonal imbalance and irregular cycles. An alternate method of contraception can be considered only if the patient prefers to switch, but it is not an immediate solution for the current cycle's missed pills.

 

Option B. Take 4 tablets the next day, continue the remaining packet, use additional contraception (condom) and give emergency pill if h/o intercourse in the last 72 hours: Taking 4 tablets the next day is excessive and unnecessary. The correct approach is to take the last missed pill and continue as usual.

 

Option D. Take the next pill as soon as possible and continue the remaining tablets: This option neglects the need for additional contraception and emergency contraception, which are crucial to prevent pregnancy in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If a woman misses multiple oral contraceptive pills, she should take the last missed pill as soon as possible, continue the remaining packet, use additional contraception, and consider emergency contraception if she had intercourse in the last 72 hours.

questions.text: A patient with retro-positive status was started on 2nd line highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART). Which of the following can be used to monitor treatment efficacy? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Viral load

 

Viral load measurement is the primary method used to monitor the efficacy of antiretroviral therapy (ART) in patients with HIV. According to WHO and NACO guidelines, the monitoring of viral load is crucial for assessing the effectiveness of the treatment. Initially, viral load is monitored every six months until the regimen is stabilized. After that, it is monitored annually.

 

The goal of ART is to achieve an undetectable viral load, defined as less than 50 copies per mL. If the viral load is less than 50 copies, it indicates effective suppression of the virus, and the patient can continue with the same ART regimen with yearly monitoring.

 

If the viral load exceeds 1000 copies, it suggests treatment failure, necessitating a change in the ART regimen.

 

For viral loads between 50 and 1000 copies, the issue is often due to poor adherence to therapy, and it is recommended to ensure adherence and frequently monitor viral load every three months until suppression is achieved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CD4+ T cell count: Previously, CD4+ T cell count was commonly used to monitor HIV treatment. However, current guidelines prioritize viral load over CD4 count for monitoring treatment efficacy. While CD4 count is still important for assessing the immune system's health, it is not the primary marker for treatment efficacy.

 

Option C. p24 antigen: The p24 antigen is a protein associated with HIV. It is used for early detection of HIV infection but is not suitable for monitoring long-term treatment efficacy. p24 levels do not provide reliable information on viral suppression or ART effectiveness.

 

Option D. Viral serotype: Viral serotyping involves identifying different strains of HIV but does not provide information on treatment efficacy. It is more relevant in epidemiological studies and vaccine development rather than in monitoring ongoing therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Viral load measurement is the most important and recommended method for monitoring the efficacy of antiretroviral therapy in HIV patients. The goal is to achieve an undetectable viral load (<50 copies/mL).

questions.text: A patient arrives with a clean-cut injury, no lacerations. He reports receiving his last tetanus vaccination approximately a decade ago. What would be the recommended course of action? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Single dose tetanus toxoid

 

The recommended course of action for a patient with a clean-cut injury who received their last tetanus vaccination approximately a decade ago is to administer a single dose of tetanus toxoid. This recommendation is based on the standard guidelines for tetanus prophylaxis in wound management.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient with mild to moderate renal failure requires reversal of muscle relaxation induced by vecuronium. Which of the following drugs is appropriate for this purpose? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sugammadex

 

Vecuronium is a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant used during surgeries to facilitate intubation and muscle relaxation. After the procedure, it is often necessary to reverse the effects of vecuronium to allow the patient to regain muscle function.

 

Sugammadex is a selective relaxant binding agent (SRBA) specifically designed to reverse the effects of certain non-depolarizing muscle relaxants, including vecuronium and rocuronium. It works by encapsulating the vecuronium molecules, effectively reducing their availability to bind to nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction, thereby reversing muscle paralysis.

 

Sugammadex is preferred in patients with mild to moderate renal failure because it is highly effective and works faster than traditional agents like neostigmine. While Sugammadex is contraindicated in severe or end-stage renal disease due to reduced clearance, it can be safely used in mild to moderate renal impairment.

 

Note –

 

Reversal agents for muscle relaxants used in anesthesia include neostigmine and Sugammadex.

 

Neostigmine:

 

  • A cholinergic drug that inhibits acetylcholinesterase, leading to increased acetylcholine.
  • Causes cholinergic side effects due to the increased acetylcholine.
  • Can be used for all muscle relaxants.
  • Can be given in renal disease patients
  • If neostigmine is not an option and the patient has mild to moderate renal failure, Sugammadex is the preferred choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Physostigmine: Physostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, but it is primarily used to reverse the effects of central nervous system depressants and is not typically used for reversing non-depolarizing muscle relaxants like vecuronium.

 

Option B. Rivastigmine: Rivastigmine is also an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, but it is used in the management of Alzheimer's disease and other types of dementia, not for reversing muscle relaxants.

 

Option D. Succinylcholine: Succinylcholine is a depolarizing muscle relaxant used for short-term muscle relaxation, such as during intubation. It is not used for reversing the effects of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants like vecuronium and, in fact, would induce more muscle relaxation rather than reverse it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sugammadex is the appropriate agent for reversing the effects of vecuronium in patients with mild to moderate renal failure due to its specific action on non-depolarizing muscle relaxants and its faster onset of action.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a lump in the upper outer quadrant of her breast. Histopathological examination of the mass showed cells in mucin pools and faint nuclei. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Colloid carcinoma

 

The given scenario is suggestive of colloid or mucinous carcinoma of the breast.

 

This is a rare type of breast cancer that occurs more frequently in older women and grows slowly. The prognosis of colloid carcinoma is better than that of infiltrating duct carcinoma.

 

The tumor is typically a soft, gelatinous mass with well-defined borders.

 

Histologically, colloid carcinoma has a lot of extracellular epithelial mucin and mucin-filled acini. Floating in large lakes of mucin are cuboidal to tall columnar tumor cells, some of which show mucus vacuolation. Nuclei in intracellular type are pushed to the periphery, forming a signet ring appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Papillary carcinoma: Papillary carcinoma of the breast is characterized by the presence of papillary structures lined by neoplastic cells.

 

  • It does not typically present with large pools of mucin.

 

Option C. Medullary carcinoma: Medullary carcinoma is characterized by large, high-grade cells with a syncytial growth pattern, prominent lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, and pushing borders.

 

  • It lacks the extensive mucin pools seen in colloid carcinoma.

 

Option D. Lobular carcinoma: Lobular carcinoma is characterized by small, uniform cells arranged in single-file lines or targetoid patterns.

 

  • It typically lacks the mucin pools characteristic of colloid carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Colloid carcinoma of the breast, also known as mucinous carcinoma, is identified by the presence of tumor cells floating in large extracellular mucin pools. This rare type of breast cancer has a better prognosis compared to infiltrating duct carcinoma and is characterized histologically by its mucinous components.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, nocturnal cough, breathlessness, and wheezing for 4 weeks. Absolute eosinophil count > 5000/μL. Chest X-ray shows a miliary pattern. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia

 

Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia (TPE) is a condition caused by the presence of microfilariae in the pulmonary circulation, leading to a severe immune response characterized by significant eosinophilia. The clinical presentation includes fever, nocturnal cough, breathlessness, and wheezing, which are symptoms consistent with TPE. The absolute eosinophil count greater than 5000/μL further supports this diagnosis.

 

The chest X-ray finding of a miliary pattern, though more commonly associated with tuberculosis, can also be seen in TPE due to the diffuse infiltration of eosinophils in the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchial asthma: Asthma can present with wheezing and nocturnal symptoms but is not typically associated with a miliary pattern on chest X-ray or such a high level of eosinophilia.

 

Option B. Miliary tuberculosis: Miliary tuberculosis can present with a miliary pattern on chest X-ray but is not associated with a significantly elevated eosinophil count. Miliary TB usually presents with systemic symptoms like weight loss, night sweats, and widespread dissemination in the body.

 

Option D. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis: This condition can cause pulmonary symptoms and may present with a miliary pattern on imaging. However, it is usually a type III hypersensitivity reaction (immune complex-mediated) and does not typically lead to such high levels of eosinophilia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia is characterized by symptoms like fever, nocturnal cough, breathlessness, wheezing, significant eosinophilia, and a miliary pattern on chest X-ray. This diagnosis should be considered in patients presenting with these clinical findings, especially in endemic regions. The treatment of choice for TPE is diethylcarbamazine (DEC).

questions.text: A 50-year-old HIV patient presented with a painful lesion, as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Kaposi sarcoma

 

Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a common malignancy in patients with HIV/AIDS. It is caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) and typically presents as painless or painful, violaceous (purple) lesions on the skin and mucous membranes, including the oral cavity. The image shows such a lesion on the palate, which is characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma. These lesions are vascular in nature and can vary in color from red to purple, often with a raised or nodular appearance. In HIV patients, Kaposi sarcoma is an AIDS-defining condition and is often seen in those with significant immunosuppression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Basal cell carcinoma: This type of skin cancer usually occurs in sun-exposed areas of the skin and rarely affects mucous membranes. It typically presents as a pearly or waxy bump, not as multiple purple lesions.

 

Option C. Malignant melanoma: While melanomas can appear as pigmented lesions, they are usually black or brown and rarely present as multiple violaceous lesions in the oral cavity.

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma: This type of cancer can occur in the oral cavity but usually presents as a non-healing ulcer or a raised, firm, scaly plaque. It does not have the characteristic color and appearance of Kaposi sarcoma lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kaposi sarcoma should be suspected in HIV patients presenting with violaceous lesions on the skin or mucous membranes. It is an AIDS-defining condition associated with HHV-8 infection.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT used to diagnose Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE)? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Brain biopsy

 

Explanation:

 

Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE) is a rare, progressive, and fatal neurological complication of measles infection that typically occurs 7-13 years after the primary infection. The diagnosis of SSPE is based on clinical features and supporting laboratory findings, and brain biopsy can show histopathological features of SSPE (such as demyelination, gliosis, and intranuclear inclusion bodies), it is:

 

  • Invasive
  • Rarely required
  • Not part of the routine diagnostic workup, due to reliable clinical and laboratory alternatives.

     

Dyken's Diagnostic Criteria for SSPE

 

Major Criteria (Need at least 3 for diagnosis):

  1. Characteristic Clinical History and Presentation
    1. Progressive cognitive decline (e.g., intellectual deterioration)
    2. Behavioral changes
    3. Myoclonic jerks (often bilateral and symmetric)
    4. Motor dysfunction or seizures
  2. Characteristic EEG Findings
    1. Periodic, stereotyped, high-voltage discharges occurring every 4–10 seconds (often called "periodic complexes")
  3. Elevated Measles Antibody Titer in CSF
    1. Significantly elevated titers of measles-specific antibodies in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), usually disproportionately high compared to serum
  4. Elevated Measles Antibody Titer in Serum
    1. Measles IgG antibody titer in serum, often >1:256 or equivalent by ELISA
  5. Brain Biopsy or Histopathology
    1. Evidence of panencephalitis with demyelination, inclusion bodies, and gliosis on biopsy or autopsy (usually reserved for unclear cases)
    2. Minor Criteria (Supportive, but not required):
      1. History of primary measles infection, usually before 2 years of age
      2. Presence of oligoclonal bands in CSF
      3. Imaging findings (MRI) showing white matter lesions
      4. Progressive neurological decline over months to years
      5. Response to certain therapies (e.g., intraventricular interferon, isoprinosine)
         

Summary:

 

Diagnosis is typically confirmed if at least 3 of the 5 major criteria are fulfilled, especially with the clinical triad, EEG, and elevated CSF antibodies.

 

Brain biopsy is invasive and rarely needed since the diagnosis can be reliably established with less invasive methods mentioned above.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EEG - Incorrect. EEG is a crucial diagnostic tool for SSPE. It typically shows a characteristic pattern with periodic high-amplitude slow-wave complexes that occur every 4-10 seconds, known as Radermecker complexes.

 

Option C. Antibody in CSF - Incorrect. Elevated measles-specific antibodies in CSF are a key diagnostic criterion for SSPE. The CSF shows increased immunoglobulin G (IgG) with oligoclonal bands specific for measles virus.

 

Option D. Antibody in blood - Incorrect. Elevated serum measles antibody titers (typically 1:256 or higher) are an important diagnostic feature of SSPE, reflecting the immune response to persistent measles virus infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SSPE diagnosis relies on clinical features, characteristic EEG patterns, and elevated measles antibodies in both CSF and serum, with brain biopsy being unnecessary for routine diagnosis of this measles complication.

questions.text: A first year MBBS student presented to OPD with intermittent episodes of impending doom accompanied by profuse sweating. The episodes usually occur before her exams. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Panic disorder

 

The symptoms described are indicative of panic attacks, which are sudden periods of intense fear or discomfort that may include palpitations, sweating, trembling or shaking, and feelings of impending doom. These attacks can occur unexpectedly or in anticipation of a specific trigger, such as before an exam.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Conversion disorder is characterized by neurological symptoms not explained by a neurological disease or other medical condition.

 

Option C. Social anxiety disorder is characterized by an intense fear of social situations.

 

Option D. Generalized anxiety disorder involves excessive anxiety and worry about multiple events or activities most days for at least 6 months, not limited to performance situations like exams.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent episodes of panic attack. Panic attack is a sudden, intense episode of fear or discomfort often accompanied by a sensation of impending doom. The symptoms during panic attack usually involve sudden onset of palpitations, chest pain, choking sensations, dizziness and feeling of unreality (depersonalization or derealization).Along with these physical symptoms there is also fear of dying, losing control or going mad.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 394.

questions.text: Which fungus is most commonly associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rhizopus

 

Rhizopus is the most common fungus associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis.

 

Diabetic patients are immunocompromised and so prone to develop opportunistic infections. Orbital cellulitis with Rhizopus may turn fatal in these patients as it is an angioinvasive fungus and could lead to septicemia and thromboses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida: Incorrect, although Candida is a common opportunistic pathogen, it is more frequently associated with mucocutaneous and systemic infections rather than orbital cellulitis.

 

Option C. Aspergillus: Incorrect, Aspergillus can cause a variety of infections including orbital cellulitis, but it is not the most common cause in the context of diabetic ketoacidosis.

 

Option D. Trichophyton: Incorrect, Trichophyton primarily causes skin infections such as ringworm and athlete's foot, and is not typically associated with orbital cellulitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhizopus is the predominant fungal pathogen linked with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis, underscoring the critical need for prompt diagnosis and aggressive treatment in such high-risk groups to prevent severe complications.

choices.text: Anthracotic pigment

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presented with cough, fatigability, and weight loss. He was diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) on bronchoscopy. The resected specimen had a hilar lymph node that was 1cm in size and showed a black pigment. What is the black pigment likely to be? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anthracotic pigment

 

The black pigment in the resected bronchoscopic specimen's hilar lymph node is most likely an anthracotic pigment.

 

The black colour is caused by carbon particle deposition. Carbon particles inhaled are engulfed by lung macrophages and transported to the hilar lymph nodes. This builds up and causes anthracosis, or blackening of the lung tissues.

 

 

It is commonly seen in people who work in environments with high levels of carbon particle pollution, such as coal mines. It is also the most common exogenous pigment found in humans as a result of urban air pollution. The aggregates of the carbon dust may induce fibroblastic reaction or emphysema that may lead to a condition called coal worker's pneumoconiosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Melanin: Melanin is a natural pigment found in the skin, hair, and eyes. It is not typically found in the lungs or lymph nodes.

 

Option C. Lipochrome: Lipochrome (also known as lipofuscin) is a yellow-brown pigment that accumulates with age in various tissues, but it does not present as black and is not typically found in the lungs or lymph nodes.

 

Option D. Hemosiderin: Hemosiderin is an iron-storage complex and presents as a golden-brown pigment. It is associated with hemorrhage and iron metabolism but does not appear as black.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anthracotic pigment, resulting from the deposition of carbon particles, is the most likely cause of the black pigment observed in the hilar lymph node of a patient with squamous cell carcinoma. This is common in individuals exposed to high levels of environmental pollution or occupational hazards involving carbon particles.

questions.text: Identify the child whose growth is compromised: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Line C

 

The growth trajectory marked as "C" on the chart indicates compromised growth. This line is positioned below the 3rd percentile curve, which suggests that the child's weight for age is significantly below what is expected for her age, placing her in a category that may be indicative of undernutrition or an underlying health condition that is affecting her growth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: This trajectory follows closely along the 50th percentile, indicating normal growth patterns according to WHO standards.

 

Option B: Although this trajectory starts near the 15th percentile, it remains consistently parallel to the standard growth curves, suggesting stable growth that remains proportionate over time, albeit at a lower percentile.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pediatric health assessments, growth charts are critical tools. They help healthcare providers monitor a child's growth over time, comparing their progress against standardized percentile curves. A trajectory like "C", which falls below the 3rd percentile, warrants further investigation to determine the cause of the poor growth and to initiate appropriate interventions.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, and the x-ray showed the following features. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Putty kidney

 

Given patient with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria along with the given x-ray points to a diagnosis of a putty kidney.

 

GENITOURINARY TB

 

C/F - Increased frequency of urine

Urine Analysis - Sterile pyuria

Most Sensitive Investigation - IVP

Sign - Moth eaten calyces (irregularity of calyces d/t inflammation caused by TB bacillus)

Bladder - Thimble bladder (low volume bladder because of persistent inflammation)

END STAGE: Putty kidney [lobar calcification of kidney]

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nephrocalcinosis:  Calcium deposits in the kidney tissue itself due to any disorder that leads to high levels of calcium in the blood or urine

 

 

Option C. Staghorn calculi: usually develop due to prolonged urinary tract infections caused by urease-producing bacteria, such as Proteus, Klebsiella, and Pseudomonas species. Commonly composed of struvite.

 

 

Option D. Psoas calcification: This refers to calcification within the psoas muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Putty kidney is an advanced renal pathology often resulting from chronic infections such as tuberculosis, leading to extensive calcification and renal dysfunction. This condition is distinguishable on imaging by its irregular, extensive calcifications throughout the kidney, associated with clinical symptoms like abdominal pain and sterile pyuria.

questions.text: Implantation of the fertilized ovum typically occurs on which day post-fertilization? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Day 5

 

Explanation:

 

Implantation typically occurs between the 6th to 10th day post-fertilization. According to embryological references such as Langevin and Larson, implantation generally begins around the 5th to 6th day. However, in this specific question, since Day 6 is not listed among the options, the best available choice is Day 5, which aligns closely with the actual timing of implantation onset.

 

During early embryogenesis, the blastocyst stage, which is the stage right before implantation, is typically reached around Day 5. At this point, the blastocyst is ready to implant into the uterine wall, initiating the process of establishing pregnancy.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Implantation typically begins around the 5th to 6th day after fertilization, with Day 5 often representing the initial attachment of the blastocyst to the uterine lining. If Day 6 is not an option, choose the next closest day, which is Day 5.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the point from A to C in the given flowchart depicting the natural history of a disease? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Lead time

 

Lead time is defined as the interval between the point a condition is detected through screening and the Time it would normally have been detected due to appearance and reporting of signs and symptoms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Screening time:  This term refers to the period during which screening tests are conducted to detect disease in asymptomatic individuals.

 

Option C. Lag time:  This term is generally used to describe a delay between the onset of an event and its detection or measurement. In the context of disease, lag time could refer to the delay between symptom onset and diagnosis.

 

Option D. Generation time:  This term is typically used in epidemiology to describe the time interval between the infection of a host and the subsequent transmission of the disease to another host. It does not relate to the timeline of diagnosis within an individual patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lead time is the interval between the detection of a disease through screening and its usual time of diagnosis due to symptom presentation.

 

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening (leading the time of diagnosis)

 

Early detection of disease due to screening (B rather than C) will ensure earlier institution of treatment, thus better prognosis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was suffering from low grade fever, inspiratory stridor and barking cough for past 5 days. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the cause of this condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parainfluenza

 

Barking cough is a feature of laryngotracheobronchitis, which is caused by the parainfluenza virus. The X-ray finding is the 'Steeple sign' due to subglottic narrowing.

 

The age of presentation of laryngotracheobronchitis ranges from 6 months-6 years. The clinical features include barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, low-grade fever.

 

Management:

 

  • ﻿﻿Racemic epinephrine nebulization leads to the rapid improvement of upper airway obstruction.
  • Epinephrine constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid resorption and improvement in airway edema.
  • ﻿﻿Dexamethasone-by the least invasive route (Oral>|V>|M). It is indicated in all the grades of croup.
  • ﻿﻿Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (Sp02 <92 %)

 

Antibiotics are not indicated in laryngotracheobronchitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Moraxella: More commonly associated with conditions like otitis media and sinusitis rather than croup.

 

Option C. Haemophilus influenzae: Although capable of causing respiratory tract infections, it is not a typical cause of croup.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus: Known for more severe respiratory conditions like bacterial tracheitis, which is distinct from viral croup and presents with more severe symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parainfluenza is a common cause of croup. The 'Steeple sign' on X-ray supports this diagnosis, emphasizing the need for prompt and effective treatment to ensure rapid recovery and prevent complications.

questions.text: A middle aged cement factory worker has developed mesothelioma. This is likely to be associated with: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asbestosis

 

Mesothelioma is a malignant tumor of the pleura (or less commonly, the peritoneum). The development of mesothelioma is closely linked with exposure to asbestos, which is commonly encountered in certain occupational settings, including cement factories.

 

Asbestosis:

 

  • Pathology: Asbestosis refers to chronic lung disease caused by inhaling asbestos fibers. The fibers can cause inflammation and scarring of lung tissue, leading to a restrictive lung disease.
  • Complications: Prolonged exposure to asbestos can lead to the development of mesothelioma, a malignant tumor of the pleura or peritoneum.
  • Occupational Exposure: Cement factory workers, construction workers, and shipbuilders are at higher risk of asbestos exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silicosis: Caused by inhalation of silica dust, leading to nodular pulmonary fibrosis. Not directly associated with mesothelioma.

 

Option C. Anthracosis: Associated with coal dust inhalation, leading to coal worker's pneumoconiosis, not mesothelioma.

 

Option D. Byssinosis: Associated with cotton dust inhalation, leading to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, not mesothelioma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mesothelioma is strongly associated with asbestos exposure, commonly found in occupations such as cement factory work, construction, and shipbuilding. Asbestosis can lead to significant complications, including mesothelioma.

 

Asbestos is a fibrous silicate mineral used in insulation, construction, and cement manufacturing.

 

  • Inhaled asbestos fibers lodge in the lungs and pleura, causing:
  • Interstitial fibrosis (asbestosis)
  • Pleural plaques
  • Mesothelioma
  • Increased risk of bronchogenic carcinoma
  • Even minimal exposure can be dangerous over time.

questions.text: Among the given options, murmur given in the image is associated with? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mitral Regurgitation

 

The image provided indicates a murmur occurring between S1 and S2, which is described as a pan-systolic murmur. This type of murmur spans the entirety of systole.

 

Mitral Regurgitation produces a pan-systolic murmur due to the backward flow of blood from the left ventricle into the left atrium throughout systole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic Regurgitation: Characterized by an early diastolic murmur due to backflow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle.

 

Option C. Mitral Stenosis: Characterized by a mid-diastolic murmur due to obstructed blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle during diastole.

 

Option D. Aortic Stenosis: Characterized by an ejection systolic murmur due to turbulent blood flow across a narrowed aortic valve during systole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitral regurgitation is associated with a pan-systolic murmur, which is present throughout the systole and heard between the S1 and S2 heart sounds.

questions.text: An individual undergoes a bone marrow examination which shows the presence of the cells as shown in the image. Which of the following is the likely enzyme defect associated with this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucocerebrosidase

 

The presence of gaucher cells with a crumpled paper appearance is suggestive of Gaucher’s disease. It is caused by deficiency of glucocerebrosidase.

 

Gaucher's Disease:

 

  • Pathology: Gaucher's disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. This enzyme is responsible for breaking down glucocerebroside into glucose and ceramide.
  • Clinical Features: Patients may present with hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and bone pain or fractures.
  • Histopathology: Gaucher cells are macrophages filled with lipid-laden lysosomes. These cells have a characteristic crumpled paper appearance due to the accumulation of glucocerebroside.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hexosaminidase: Deficiency causes Tay-Sachs disease, characterized by a cherry-red spot on the macula.

 

Option C. Alpha 1,4 glucosidase: Deficiency causes Pompe disease, characterized by glycogen accumulation in lysosomes.

 

Option D. Galactosidase: Deficiency causes Fabry disease, characterized by angiokeratomas, acroparesthesia, and renal failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gaucher cells with a crumpled paper appearance in a bone marrow examination are indicative of Gaucher's disease, caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase.

 

Gaucher Disease Overview:

questions.text: Which part of scaphoid is most susceptible to avascular necrosis? (NEET PG  2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Proximal 1/3rd

 

SCAPHOID FRACTURE

 

  • Salient features: 

    • It is the most commonly fractured bone in the carpus, in adult as well as children. 

    • Most commonly in males between the ages of 15 and 30. 

    • Fullness and tenderness in anatomical snuff box. 

    • Proximal pressure along the axis of the thumb may be painful.

  • Most common location:              

    • Adults and adolescents: Middle third (Waist) fractures (70%) > proximal pole fracture (20%) > distal pole fracture (10%). 

    • Children: Distal pole avulsion type fracture.

  • Pathogenesis of AVN:

    • Most of the blood supply to the scaphoid enters distally, so blood supply of scaphoid diminishes proximally. 

    • This accounts for the fact that 1% of distal third, 20% of middle third, 40% of proximal third and 100% of proximal pole fractures result in avascular necrosis or non-union of the proximal fragment.

    • Thus, the proximal third of the scaphoid is most susceptible to avascular necrosis (AVN) due to its precarious retrograde blood supply. 

    • Fracture in the waist (middle third) can disrupt this blood flow to the proximal fragment, leading to AVN.

  • Diagnosis: 

    • A wrist sprain that is sufficiently severe to require radiographic examination initially should be treated as a possible fracture of the scaphoid, and radiographs should be repeated in 2 weeks even though initial radiographs may be negative.

    • Recent fracture shows only in the oblique view.

    • MRI can diagnose occult fractures.

    • MRI, especially with gadolinium enhancement, also is useful in assessing the vascularity of a fractured scaphoid.

  • Treatment:

    • Nondisplaced, Stable Scaphoid Fractures: Scaphoid Glass Holding Cast.

    • Displaced, Unstable Scaphoid Fractures: Headless Screw (Herbert) is used

    • Complication: Non-union > Avascular Necrosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Distal 1/3rd. Distal 1/3rd portion of the scaphoid is a well vascularized area, so fracture to this part is often undisplaced or minimally displaced, thus they heal faster with conservative management. This portion of scaphoid is fractured in 10% of cases. AVN of this part occurs in 1% cases. 

 

Option B. Middle 1/3rd. Middle 1/3rd or the waist of scaphoid is most commonly fractures, accounting for 70% of cases. But the chances of AVN at this portion are around 20%. 

 

Option D. Scaphoid tubercle. Avulsion fracture of scaphoid tubercle are rare. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The proximal 1/3rd portion of the scaphoid have less chances of fracture (20%) but have higher chances of AVN (40%).

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman was involved in a car accident two months ago, and she now complains of screaming and waking up in the middle of the night after having nightmares about the same incident over and over. Which of the following conditions does she have? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Post traumatic stress disorder

 

This woman's presentation of recurrent nightmares about a traumatic event (the car accident) that happened two months ago suggests Post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). PTSD can develop after a traumatic event and involves symptoms such as re-experiencing the trauma (e.g., flashbacks, nightmares), avoidance of reminders of the trauma, negative alterations in mood and cognition, and increased arousal (e.g., irritability, difficulty sleeping).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute stress reaction: Acute stress reaction typically occurs immediately after a traumatic event and lasts for a few days to a few weeks.

 

Option B. Adjustment disorder: Adjustment disorder develops in response to a stressor and is characterized by emotional and behavioral symptoms, rather than the nightmares. It arises within three months of the stressor.

 

Option C. Mania: Mania is characterized by elevated mood, increased energy, and decreased need for sleep, among other symptoms, and isn't directly related to a traumatic event.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PTSD manifests after experiencing or witnessing significant traumatic event, with symptoms like flashbacks, nightmares,hypervigilance, exaggerated startle response,  severe anxiety centered on the event and avoidance of the situations that remind of the trauma. The symptoms must be present for at least one month. It is more common in females and young adults. Hippocampus and amygdala are implicated in the etiology of PTSD. Treatment includes trauma-focussed CBT (treatment of choice), SSRIs (Drug of choice), and eye movements desensitization and reprocessing.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 439-441.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for the insertion of the device shown in the image below? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trophoblastic disease

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given image shows a copper-containing IUCD (intrauterine contraceptive device).
  • ABSOLUTE c/I to an Intra-uterine device are:
    • Unexplained uterine or vaginal bleeding
    • Post abortal sepsis/ Puerperal sepsis/ Current Pelvic inflammatory/ disease, Genital Tuberculosis
    • Cancers: Endometrial cancer, Cervical cancer, Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia
    • Large fibroid distorting the uterine cavity, Mullerian anomalies distorting the uterine cavity

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Menstruation: Intra-uterine device can be inserted even during periods although preferably it should be inserted post-menstrual

 

Option C. Immediately after delivery: This is called as Post placental IUCD insertion (within 10 mins of placental delivery)

 

Option D. Ruptured condom during intercourse: Following a ruptured condom, CUT can be inserted as an emergency contraception

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trophoblastic disease is an ABSOLUTE c/I to an Intra-uterine device.

 

Ref: https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789241549158

questions.text: Which of the following condition will cause intermittent breaking of long bones in a child? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Osteogenesis Imperfecta

 

OSTEOGENESIS IMPERFECTA

 

  • It is a genetic disorder of connective tissue determined by quantitative and qualitative defect in type I collagen formation.
  • There is alteration in the structural integrity, or a reduction in the total amount of type I collagen.
  • Most common cause of multiple fractures in childhood.
  • It is also known as Lobstein-Vrolik brittle bone disease.
  • It is inherited from a parent in autosomal dominant (AD) fashion, or may occur as spontaneous mutation, or, rarely as autosomal recessive (AR) trait.
  • Clinical features:
    • The defining clinical feature is osteopenia, causing repeated propensity to fracture, generally after minor trauma and often without much pain or swelling.
    • According to the severity of disease, fractures may occur in uterus, at birth, or after birth prior to or after walking age.
    • Lower limb fractures are more common than upper limb.
    • Femur is commonest bone fractured followed by tibia.
    • Frequency of fractures decline sharply after adolescence or puberty, although it may rise again in postmenopausal (climacteric) women.
    • Hyperlaxity of ligaments, with resultant hypermobility of joint is common.
    • Rarely recurrent dislocation of patella, radial head and hip joint dislocation and DDH can occur.
    • Blue/gray sclera due to uveal pigment visible through thin collagen layer.
    • Deafness due to otosclerosis/pressure on auditory nerve
    • Dentinogenesis imperfect/crumbling of teeth i.e., deciduous and permanent teeth break easily and become prone to carries. Lower incisors severely affected.
    • Skin becomes thin and translucent. Subcutaneous hemorrhages may occur.
    • Muscles are hypotonic due to multiple fractures and deformities.
       
  • Prenatal diagnosis: Abnormal Pro a chain
  • Radiological features:
    • Wormian bones (detached portions of primary ossification centers of adjacent membrane bones) are seen in skull X-ray. It should be more than 10 in number, measure at least 6 × 4 mm, and arranged in mosaic pattern.
    • Ring-shaped epiphysis is seen
    • Skeleton: White crumpled-bone shaped not maintained

 

 

  • Classification: SILLENCE classification
  • Treatment: 
    • Bisphosphonates to decrease osteoclastic bone resorption
    • Ideal treatment: replace COLIAI or COLIA2 gene.
       
  • SOFIELD MILLER surgery (SEEKH KEBAB surgery)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Achondroplasia. It is a primary defect of endochondral bone formation. Autosomal dominant but 80% are spontaneous mutations. It is the effect of excessive growth hormone on the mature skeleton. Paternal age >36 year is linked with new mutation. It is most common form of disproportionate dwarfism.
