Disproportionate rhizomelic micromelia is most severe in proximal limbs. Trunk height is be normal, but arm span and standing height are diminished. Skull is large with prominent forehead (frontal bossing), saddle-shaped nose (flat and depressed nasal bridge), small maxilla, prominent mandibles and normal dentition. The patients have normal intelligence, trident hand (separation between middle and ring fingers) and starfish hand (middle finger shorter). The vertebrae shows short interpedicular distance, bullet shape. The pelvis appears like a champagne glass (pelvic width > depth). Hooked vertebra are seen.

 

 

 

Option B. Marfan syndrome. It is the Fibrillin 1 defect. There is a disproportionate increase in the height. The limbs are long and there is arachnodactyly (fingers and hand are long and have spider-like appearance). Scoliosis, Pectus excavatum/Pectus carinatum, Hyperlaxity, High-arched palate, Pes planus, and Hammer toes are seen. Early OA is a feature. Ghent criterion is used for diagnosis of Marfan syndrome.

 

 

Option D. Cretinism. Cretinism is a condition of severely stunted physical and mental growth due to untreated congenital deficiency of thyroid hormones (congenital hypothyroidism). Congenital hypothyroidism can be endemic, genetic, or sporadic. Sporadic and genetic cretinism results from abnormal development, or function of the foetal thyroid gland. Cretinism has been almost completely eliminated in developed countries by early diagnosis by newborn screening schemes and iodine supplementation programs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intermittent breaking of long bones in children is a feature of osteogenesis imperfecta.

choices.text: Rosette cataract with control of blood sugar level
Immature cataract with Phacoemulsification + IOL implantation

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient complaints of blurring of vision and gives history of Diabetes for the past 10 years. On examination findings as shown in image were seen. What is the most likely diagnosis and treatment for the same. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Immature cataract with Phacoemulsification + IOL implantation

 

Immature cataract refers to a cataract that has not yet progressed to cause complete opacity and loss of vision. Phacoemulsification is a modern cataract surgery technique that uses ultrasonic vibrations to emulsify the lens, allowing for its removal and replacement with an IOL. This is a common treatment for cataracts that are significantly affecting vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sunflower Cataract with Lens Extraction: Sunflower cataract is characterized by the presence of a central, sunflower-like opacity on the lens. It is commonly associated with conditions such as Wilson's disease, where copper deposits on the lens. Treatment typically involves surgical removal of the cataractous lens (lens extraction), often followed by the implantation of an artificial intraocular lens (IOL).

 

Option B. Rosette Cataract with Control of Blood Sugar Level: A rosette cataract usually forms a star-shaped pattern and is often associated with trauma. While controlling blood sugar levels is essential for patients with diabetes to prevent the progression of diabetic retinopathy and other complications, it may not reverse the changes already present in the lens.

 

Option D. Zonular Cataract with Lensectomy: Zonular cataract refers to the opacities that affect the zone or region of the lens. A lensectomy involves the surgical removal of the lens, which can be applied to different types of cataracts, often followed by the placement of an IOL.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The diagnosis of cataracts involves a thorough examination of the lens using slit-lamp microscopy or similar diagnostic tools. Understanding the underlying causes, such as diabetes, and recognizing the specific patterns associated with different types of cataracts are crucial for determining the appropriate treatment, which often involves surgery to restore vision. Regular monitoring and management of blood sugar levels are essential in diabetic patients to prevent or slow the progression of diabetic cataracts.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with cola colored urine and had a history of skin infection few days back. His creatinine value was initially 2.5 mg/dl but even after 3 weeks of treatment it increased to 4.5 mg/dl. Which of the following is a likely kidney biopsy finding on electron microscopy? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subepithelial deposits

 

A child with skin infection followed by passage of cola colored urine is suggestive of post streptococcal glomerulonephritis. The worsening of creatinine from 2.5mg/dl to 4.5 mg/dl is suggestive of worsen of his condition in a short span of time. This prompts a diagnosis of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN).

 

Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN):

 

  • Pathology: RPGN is characterized by the presence of crescents in the glomeruli, which are formed by the proliferation of parietal epithelial cells and infiltration of monocytes and macrophages.
  • Clinical Features: Rapid deterioration of renal function, often following an infection such as streptococcal throat or skin infection.
  • Crescents can be seen on light microscopy in RPGN (especially crescentic PSGN).
  • But electron microscopy (EM) will still show subepithelial deposits, which is diagnostic of PSGN.
  • So, even though the clinical course is RPGN, the question asked what you see on EM - hence the correct answer is Subepithelial deposits
  • Type I: Anti-GBM disease (Goodpasture syndrome)
  • Type II: Immune complex-mediated (e.g., PSGN, lupus nephritis)
  • Type III: Pauci-immune (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, also known as Wegener’s)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subendothelial deposits: Seen in conditions like lupus nephritis and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, not typical for RPGN following PSGN.

 

Option C. Crescents in glomeruli: Suggest RPGN, but the specific hallmark of PSGN is subepithelial humps (crescents may appear if it evolves into RPGN, but not diagnostic)

 

Option D. Mesangial deposits: Commonly seen in IgA nephropathy and other mesangioproliferative glomerulonephritis, not specific for RPGN.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of crescents in the glomeruli on kidney biopsy is characteristic of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN), especially in a patient with worsening renal function following an episode of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. However, crescents can be seen on light microscopy.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases have autosomal recessive inheritance? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Albinism

 

Albinism is typically inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. To have albinism, an individual must inherit two copies of the mutated gene for albinism, one from each parent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. G-6-PD deficiency: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G-6-PD) deficiency is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner, not autosomal recessive. It affects males more often than females.

 

Option C. Marfan's syndrome: Marfan's syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, not autosomal recessive. A single copy of the mutated gene from one parent is enough to cause the condition.

 

Option D. Lesch-Nyhan syndrome: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner. It primarily affects males who inherit the mutated gene from their carrier mothers.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The given chest X-ray is suggestive of: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tetralogy of Fallot

 

The given chest X-ray is suggestive of the Tetralogy of Fallot. The boot-shaped cardiac silhouette is seen due to the right ventricular hypertrophy and upward shift of the cardiac apex.

 

Tetralogy of Fallot is a congenital heart defect that affects the structure of the heart, specifically the four major components of the heart: the pulmonary valve, the right ventricle, the ventricular septum, and the aortic valve. It is a combination of four heart defects, which are:

 

  1. Pulmonary stenosis - narrowing of the pulmonary valve, which reduces blood flow to the lungs.
  2. Ventricular septal defect - a hole in the wall that separates the right and left ventricles, which allows oxygen-poor and oxygen-rich blood to mix.
  3. Overriding aorta - the aorta is located over the ventricular septal defect, which allows blood to flow from both the left and right ventricles to the body.
  4. Right ventricular hypertrophy - thickening of the right ventricle due to increased workload, which can lead to heart failure.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atrial septal defect (ASD): This condition typically shows plethoric lung fields and a wide, fixed split of S2. The X-ray findings in the question do not correlate with ASD, as it does not present with a boot-shaped heart.

 

Option C. Ventricular septal defect (VSD): VSD usually shows wide, variable splitting of S2 and plethoric lung fields due to increased pulmonary blood flow. The X-ray findings described do not match VSD.

 

Option D. Ebstein's anomaly: This condition often presents with a box-shaped heart due to maternal lithium intake during pregnancy. The X-ray findings in the question do not show a box-shaped heart, thus not fitting Ebstein's anomaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The boot-shaped heart on a chest X-ray is indicative of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), a congenital heart defect characterized by pulmonary stenosis, ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient presents with lower abdominal pain, frequent urination, and signs of dehydration. Physical examination reveals abdominal tenderness, and urine analysis indicates sterile pyuria. An image is provided. What is the most likely condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Putty kidney

 

  • The given image finding of a putty kidney is suggestive of genitourinary tuberculosis (TB).
  • Putty kidney is characterized by a homogenous and ground glass-like calcification of the kidney.
  • Genitourinary TB is a cause of sterile pyuria and is always a secondary TB caused by dissemination through the bloodstream.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by a tuberculin test or acid-fast bacilli staining and culture of urine samples.
  • CT urography is the preferred imaging modality for visualizing renal calcifications and assessing the various stages of renal TB.
  • Treatment involves short-course therapy with antitubercular drugs and surgical intervention may be necessary, such as partial nephrectomy, nephrectomy, or reconstructive surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nephrocalcinosis: Is the deposition of calcium in the kidney parenchyma or tubules, seen in hypercalcemia conditions like hyperparathyroidism.

 

Option C. Staghorncalculus: Kidney stones are a type of large urinary calculus that takes up a large portion of the urinary collecting area in the kidney. They often present in only one kidney, but in up to 15% of cases, they form in both. They often form due to recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs).

 

Option D. Psoas calcification: Refers to the calcification (formation of calcium deposits) in the psoas muscle, which is a large muscle in the lower back that plays a role in hip flexion and trunk stabilization. Psoas calcification is not directly related to kidney or urinary system conditions and may have other underlying causes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Putty kidney is a radiographic finding associated with genitourinary tuberculosis, characterized by homogenous, ground glass-like calcifications in the kidney.
  •  This condition typically presents with symptoms such as sterile pyuria, and diagnosis is confirmed through specific TB testing and imaging modalities like CT urography.
  •  Treatment usually involves antitubercular drugs and may require surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presented to the urologist with complaints of abdominal pain and recurrent urinary tract infections. Upon examination, the physician noted tenderness in the lower abdomen and a palpable mass in the right flank area. Further evaluation revealed the following. What is the likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pelviureteric junction obstruction

 

The clinical scenario and the imaging indicate a likely diagnosis of pelviureteric junction (PUJ) obstruction.

 

  • Pelviureteric junction obstruction is a condition where there is a blockage at the point where the renal pelvis meets the ureter.
  • This blockage can lead to hydronephrosis, which is the swelling of a kidney due to a buildup of urine.
  • PUJ obstruction can be congenital (present at birth) or acquired. Symptoms can include flank pain, recurrent UTIs, and a palpable mass in severe cases.
  • The findings from imaging studies, showing hydronephrosis (dilated pelvicalyceal system), would support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Putty kidney: A putty kidney refers to a kidney that has been extensively damaged by tuberculosis. The kidney appears pale, and is often shrunk, firm, and non-functional. It would not typically cause a palpable mass and recurrent UTIs in the described manner of the patient in the question.

 

Option C. Staghorn calculus: Staghorn calculi are large kidney stones that occupy a large portion of the renal pelvis and its calyces, often having a shape resembling a stag's horn. They can lead to recurrent UTIs and can sometimes be palpable, especially if the kidney is also enlarged due to obstruction. However, the description in the question and the image seems more indicative of an obstruction at the PUJ rather than a staghorn calculus.

 

Option D. Cystic kidney: A cystic kidney, as the name suggests, is characterized by multiple cysts in the kidney. There are several diseases, like polycystic kidney disease, that can lead to cyst formation in kidneys. These cysts can sometimes cause pain, enlarged kidneys, and in some cases, recurrent UTIs. However, the specific findings from the imaging study mentioned in the question don't necessarily align with a simple cystic kidney diagnosis.

 

Given the findings mentioned in the question, a palpable mass in the right flank area, tenderness in the lower abdomen, and imaging results, Pelviureteric junction obstruction (Option A) is the most consistent and likely diagnosis for the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pelviureteric junction obstruction is a condition causing blockage where the renal pelvis meets the ureter, leading to hydronephrosis and symptoms like flank pain and recurrent UTIs.
  • Imaging typically shows a dilated pelvicalyceal system.

questions.text: Identify the size of the given blade used for incision and drainage of a superficial abscess and arteriotomy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 11

 

The blade shown in the image is number 11 blade used for skin incisions (E.g., Incision and Drainage) and Arteriotomy

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

11 number blade is used In stab incisions needed when lancing an abscess or inserting a chest drain and in skin incisions and arteriotomy

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the clinic with a complaint of the feeling of insects crawling under the skin. Which of the following drug abuse can cause the symptoms of this patient?( NEET PG 2020 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cocaine

 

The sensation of insects or bugs crawling on or under the skin, known as "formication", is classically associated with cocaine use. While it can also be seen with the use of other stimulants, including amphetamines, it is most emblematic of cocaine intoxication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cannabis: Typically results in effects like altered perception, increased appetite, and paranoia.

 

Option C. Amphetamine: Another stimulant that can lead to increased energy, euphoria, and sometimes similar tactile hallucinations.

 

Option D. Alcohol: Produces symptoms such as impaired judgment, slurred speech, and incoordination.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cocaine intoxication can lead to tactile hallucinations, notably the sensation known as formication. This sensation, often described as feeling like bugs crawling on or under the skin, is a classic symptom of cocaine use and can lead to skin picking and resultant lesions. This is also known as cocaine bugs or magnun phenomenon.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 676.
